summary: This is the U.S. Government's omnibus opposition memorandum to Ghislaine Maxwell's twelve pre-trial motions in her criminal case (S1 20 Cr. 330). It argues against motions to dismiss based on Jeffrey Epstein's non-prosecution agreement, statute of limitations, pre-indictment delay, and multiplicity; motions to suppress evidence obtained via subpoena; motions to sever counts and strike surplusage; and various disclosure requests. The document provides detailed factual and legal arguments supporting the prosecution's position.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant charged with six counts including conspiracy to entice minors to travel for illegal sex acts, transportation of minors for illegal sex acts, and perjury.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: Deceased financier and alleged co-conspirator with Maxwell; his 2007 non-prosecution agreement with the Southern District of Florida is a central issue in the motion.

persons.name: Audrey Strauss
persons.context: The United States Attorney for the Southern District of New York who submitted this opposition memorandum.

persons.name: R. Alexander Acosta
persons.context: Former U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida who signed the 2007 non-prosecution agreement with Jeffrey Epstein.

persons.name: Maria Villafaña
persons.context: Former prosecutor in the USAO-SDFL who negotiated the Epstein NPA; cited in the OPR report regarding the scope of the 'co-conspirator' provision.

persons.name: Andrew Lourie
persons.context: Former supervisor at the USAO-SDFL involved in the Epstein NPA negotiations.

persons.name: Kenneth Starr
persons.context: Attorney for Jeffrey Epstein who protested compliance with the NPA and appealed to Main Justice.

persons.name: David Boies
persons.context: Founder of Boies Schiller Flexner, the law firm that represented Virginia Giuffre in her civil defamation suit against Maxwell. The government denies allegations of collusion with his firm.

persons.name: Peter Skinner
persons.context: Attorney at Boies Schiller who met with AUSA-1 in February 2016 regarding Epstein.

persons.name: Brad Edwards
persons.context: Attorney for Virginia Giuffre who met with AUSA-1 in February 2016.

persons.name: Stan Pottinger
persons.context: Attorney for Virginia Giuffre who met with AUSA-1 in February 2016 and had a follow-up call in May 2016.

persons.name: Ross Gow
persons.context: Spokesman for Ghislaine Maxwell who made statements calling Virginia Giuffre's claims 'obvious lies,' leading to the defamation suit.

persons.name: Judge Loretta A. Preska
persons.context: Judge who ordered the unsealing of Maxwell's deposition transcripts in the civil case.

persons.name: Chief Judge Colleen McMahon
persons.context: Judge who granted the government's ex parte application to modify the protective order to allow Boies Schiller to comply with a grand jury subpoena.

persons.name: Judge Robert W. Sweet
persons.context: Former judge overseeing the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil case who entered the original protective order; passed away before ruling on the government's application.

persons.name: Judge Cathy Seibel
persons.context: Magistrate judge who denied a similar government application to modify a protective order in a different civil case.

persons.name: Judge Alison J. Nathan
persons.context: Presiding judge in the criminal case (referred to as AJN in the caption).

persons.name: Dr. Bernard R. Siskin
persons.context: Statistical expert who prepared an affidavit regarding jury composition analysis for the government.

connections.description: Alleged co-conspirators in a scheme to entice and transport minors for illegal sex acts.
Maxwell was the defendant in a civil defamation lawsuit filed by Giuffre, which led to the depositions underlying the perjury charges.
Acosta, as U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, signed the 2007 non-prosecution agreement with Epstein.
Attorneys from Boies Schiller met with AUSA-1 in February 2016 to present information about Epstein. The government denies further collusion.
Maxwell is alleged to have groomed and facilitated the abuse of this minor victim by Epstein.
Maxwell is alleged to have groomed and facilitated the abuse of this minor victim by Epstein; Maxwell denied giving her a massage in her deposition.
Maxwell is alleged to have groomed this minor victim for sexual activity with Epstein; her experiences are part of the conspiracy allegations.

events.title: Epstein Non-Prosecution Agreement
events.description: Jeffrey Epstein enters into a non-prosecution agreement (NPA) with the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of Florida, which included a provision regarding 'potential co-conspirators.'

events.title: Giuffre Files Defamation Lawsuit
events.description: Virginia Giuffre files a civil defamation lawsuit against Ghislaine Maxwell in the Southern District of New York.

events.title: Maxwell's First Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is deposed by Boies Schiller attorneys in the Giuffre defamation case. Her testimony forms the basis for Count Five (perjury) of the indictment.

events.title: Maxwell's Second Deposition
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell is deposed a second time in the Giuffre defamation case. Her testimony forms the basis for Count Six (perjury) of the indictment.

events.title: SDNY Investigation Opens
events.description: The U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York initiates its investigation into Epstein and possible co-conspirators, prompted by Miami Herald reporting.

events.title: Grand Jury Subpoenas Issued
events.description: The USAO-SDNY issues grand jury subpoenas to Boies Schiller for materials related to the Giuffre v. Maxwell civil case.

events.title: Protective Order Modified
events.description: Chief Judge Colleen McMahon grants the government's ex parte application to modify the protective order in Giuffre v. Maxwell, allowing Boies Schiller to comply with the grand jury subpoena.

events.title: Maxwell Indicted
events.description: A grand jury sitting in White Plains, New York returns a sealed indictment charging Ghislaine Maxwell with six counts.

events.title: Superseding Indictment
events.description: A grand jury returns a superseding indictment with ministerial corrections.

keyFacts: The government argues Jeffrey Epstein's 2007 non-prosecution agreement does not bind the Southern District of New York and does not immunize Ghislaine Maxwell from prosecution for the crimes charged.
The government contends the indictment is timely under 18 U.S.C. § 3283, which extends the statute of limitations for crimes involving the sexual abuse of minors to the lifetime of the victim.
The government obtained Maxwell's civil deposition transcripts via a grand jury subpoena and a court order modifying a protective order, which it defends as lawful and not requiring suppression.

The perjury counts are based on allegedly false statements Maxwell made during her April and July 2016 depositions in the Giuffre defamation case, including denials about knowing of a scheme to recruit underage girls for sexual massages and about giving massages.

The government opposes severance of the perjury counts from the substantive sex trafficking counts, arguing they are logically connected and provable through overlapping evidence, including victim testimony.
